item.title: NEED BAD help with my java class homework
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:8, topic:546802”]http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/String.html

y’all stupit anyways. creating new objects every time you need a string, even if the older ones aren’t going to be used anymore psht.[/quote]

The initial string was being used again which is why I did not reuse the same object; even if I did strings are immutable, setting it to the new value creates a new string anyway.

item.title: NEED BAD help with my java class homework
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

That wouldn’t compile… but here is your solution (assuming the way you are attempting to do it is correct)

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		try (Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in)) {
			System.out.println("** String operation tests: **\n");

			System.out.print("Enter a string of characters: ");

			String input = scanner.nextLine();
			System.out.printf("The string you entered is: %s%n", input);
			System.out.printf("It is %d characters long%n", input.length());

			System.out.print("Enter another string of characters that appears somewhere in the first string: ");
			String secondInput = scanner.nextLine();
			System.out.printf("The first occurrence of the string \"%s\" in the string \"%s\" is at position %d%n", secondInput, input, input.indexOf(secondInput));

			System.out.printf("Your character string is %d characters long. Enter a number between 0 and %1$d: ", input.length() - 1);

			int pos = scanner.nextInt();
			System.out.printf("The character at position you picked, position %d is %s%n", pos, input.charAt(pos));
		}
	}

Note: This does not perform any validity checks, if you do not enter the correct information it will crash.

** String operation tests: **

Enter a string of characters: The Elephant is blue
The string you entered is: The Elephant is blue
It is 20 characters long
Enter another string of characters that appears somewhere in the first string: an
The first occurrence of the string "an" in the string "The Elephant is blue" is at position 9
Your character string is 20 characters long. Enter a number between 0 and 20: 7
The character at position you picked, position 7 is p

Read full topic

item.title: NEED BAD help with my java class homework
item.dc:creator: @hi_im_bamf hi im bamf
item.description:
@hi_im_bamf wrote:

so im taking java courses in college and im having some difficulty with this problem, idk if anyone can give me some insight or help. i can’t get it to output what i want

[code]import java.util.Scanner;
public class Lab3 {

/**

  • @param args
    /
    public static void main(String[] args) {
    // TODO Auto-generated method stub
    Scanner in = new Scanner (System.in);
    System.out.println("    * String operation tests: **");
    System.out.println();
    System.out.print("Enter a string of characters: ");
    String str = in.nextLine();
    System.out.print("The string you entered is: “+ str );
    System.out.println();
    System.out.print(“It is” + (str.length( )) + “characters long”);
    System.out.println();
    System.out.print(“Enter another string of characters that appears somewhere in the first string: " );
    String letters = in.nextLine();
    System.out.print(“The first occurrence of the string “”+letters+”” in the string “+ str+” is at position”);
    int x = letters
    String x = str.indexOf(“letters”);
    System.out.println();
    int y=(str.length())-1;
    System.out.print(“Your character string is” + (str.length()) + " long. Enter a number between 0 and "+ y );
    int c = in.nextInt
    System.out.print(“The character at the position you picked”);

}

}[/code]
